action.action-desc: Ms. Ayotte (for herself, Mr. McCain, Mr. Graham, and Mr. Inhofe) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Finance

form.official-title: To amend the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 to replace the sequester established by the Budget Control Act of 2011.

section.header: Savings applied to the fiscal year 2013 discretionary sequester

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the sequester for fiscal year 2013 for discretionary spending under section 251A(7)(A) of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 shall not be implemented.

The discretionary caps for fiscal year 2013 provided in section 251 of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act 1985, as modified by section 251A of such Act, are reduced by $10,000,000,000 in the security category and $10,000,000,000 in the non-security category.

title.header: Social security number required to claim the refundable portion of the child tax credit

section.header: Social security number required to claim the refundable portion of the child tax credit

subsection.text: Subsection (d) of section 24 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding at the end the following new paragraph:

paragraph.header: Identification requirement with respect to taxpayer

subparagraph.text: Paragraph (1) shall not apply to any taxpayer for any taxable year unless the taxpayer includes the taxpayer’s Social Security number on the return of tax for such taxable year.
In the case of a joint return, the requirement of subparagraph (A) shall be treated as met if the social security number of either spouse is included on such return.
Subparagraph (A) shall not apply to the extent the tentative minimum tax (as defined in section 55(b)(1)(A)) exceeds the credit allowed under section 32.

subsection.text: Subsection (e) of section 24 of such Code is amended by inserting With Respect to Qualifying Children after Identification Requirement in the heading thereof.
The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012.

section.header: Ending unemployment payments to jobless millionaires and billionaires

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no Federal funds may be used to make payments of unemployment compensation (including such compensation under the Federal-State Extended Compensation Act of 1970 and the emergency unemployment compensation program under title IV of the Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2008) to an individual whose adjusted gross income in the preceding year was equal to or greater than $1,000,000.

Unemployment Insurance applications shall include a form or procedure for an individual applicant to certify the individual's adjusted gross income was not equal to or greater than $1,000,000 in the preceding year.
The certifications required by (b) shall be auditable by the U.S. Department of Labor or the U.S. Government Accountability Office.

It is the duty of the states to verify the residency, employment, legal, and income status of applicants for Unemployment Insurance and no Federal funds may be expended for purposes of determining an individual's eligibility under this Act.
The prohibition under subsection (a) shall apply to weeks of unemployment beginning on or after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Preventing duplicative and overlapping government programs

subsection.text: Paragraph 11 of rule XXVI of the Standing Rules of the Senate is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating subparagraph (c) and subparagraph (d); and
by inserting after subparagraph (b) the following:

subsection.text: The report accompanying each bill or joint resolution of a public character reported by any committee (including the Committee on Appropriations and the Committee on the Budget) shall contain—

paragraph.text: an analysis by the Congressional Research Service to determine if the bill or joint resolution creates any new Federal program, office, or initiative that would duplicate or overlap any existing Federal program, office, or initiative with similar mission, purpose, goals, or activities along with a listing of all of the overlapping or duplicative Federal program or programs, office or offices, or initiative or initiatives; and

an explanation provided by the committee as to why the creation of each new program, office, or initiative is necessary if a similar program or programs, office or offices, or initiative or initiatives already exist.

subsection.text: Rule XVII of the Standing Rules of the Senate is amended by inserting at the end thereof the following:

It shall not be in order in the Senate to proceed to any bill or joint resolution unless the committee of jurisdiction has prepared and posted on the committee website an overlapping and duplicative programs analysis and explanation for the bill or joint resolution as described in subparagraph (b) prior to proceeding.
The analysis and explanation required by this subparagraph shall contain—

paragraph.text: an analysis by the Congressional Research Service to determine if the bill or joint resolution creates any new Federal program, office, or initiative that would duplicate or overlap any existing Federal program, office, or initiative with similar mission, purpose, goals, or activities along with a listing of all of the overlapping or duplicative Federal program or programs, office or offices, or initiative or initiatives; and

an explanation provided by the committee as to why the creation of each new program, office, or initiative is necessary if a similar program or programs, office or offices, or initiative or initiatives already exist.

subsection.text: This paragraph may be waived by joint agreement of the Majority Leader and the Minority Leader of the Senate upon their certification that such waiver is necessary as a result of—

paragraph.text: an emergency as determined by the leaders.

title.header: Consolidating unnecessary and duplicative and overlapping government programs

section.header: Consolidating unnecessary duplicative and overlapping government programs
section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law and not later than 150 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget shall coordinate with the heads of the relevant department and agencies to—

paragraph.text: use available administrative authority to eliminate, consolidate, or streamline Government programs and agencies with duplicative and overlapping missions identified in the—

subparagraph.text: March 2011 Government Accountability Office report to Congress entitled Opportunities to Reduce Potential Duplication in Government Programs, Save Tax Dollars, and Enhance Revenue (GAO 11 318SP); and

February 2012 Government Accountability Office report to Congress entitled 2012 Annual Report: Opportunities to Reduce Potential Duplication in Government Programs, Save Tax Dollars, and Enhance Revenue (GAO 12 342SP);

paragraph.text: identify and report to Congress any legislative changes required to further eliminate, consolidate, or streamline Government programs and agencies with duplicative and overlapping missions identified in the—

subparagraph.text: March 2011 Government Accountability Office report to Congress entitled Opportunities to Reduce Potential Duplication in Government Programs, Save Tax Dollars, and Enhance Revenue (GAO 11 318SP); and

February 2012 Government Accountability Office report to Congress entitled 2012 Annual Report: Opportunities to Reduce Potential Duplication in Government Programs, Save Tax Dollars, and Enhance Revenue (GAO 12 342SP);

paragraph.text: determine the total cost savings that shall result to each agency, office, and department from the actions described in paragraph (1); and
rescind from the appropriate accounts and apply the savings towards deficit reduction the amount greater of—

subparagraph.text: the total amount of cost savings estimated by paragraph (3).

title.header: Compensation and retirement for Federal employees and Members of Congress

section.header: Extension of pay freeze for Federal employees

subsection.text: Section 147 of the Continuing Appropriations Act, 2011 (Public Law 111–242; 5 U.S.C. 5303 note) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (b)(1), by striking December 31, 2012 and inserting December 31, 2014; and
in subsection (c), by striking December 31, 2012 and inserting December 31, 2014.

subsection.header: Clarification that freeze applies to the legislative branch

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no adjustment shall be made under section 601(a) of the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946 (2 U.S.C. 31) (relating to cost of living adjustments for Members of Congress) during the period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act and ending on December 31, 2014.

subparagraph.text: In this paragraph, the term legislative branch employee means—

clause.text: an employee whose pay is disbursed by the Secretary of the Senate or the Chief Administrative Officer of the House of Representatives; and
an employee of any agency established in the legislative branch.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no cost of living adjustment required by statute with respect to a legislative branch employee that would otherwise take effect during the period beginning on the date of enactment of this Act and ending on December 31, 2014 shall be made.

subsection.text: Section 114 of the Continuing Appropriations Resolution, 2013 (Public Law 112–175; 5 U.S.C. 5303 note) is repealed.

section.header: No cost-of-living adjustments for Members of Congress
section.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no adjustment shall be made under section 601(a) of the Legislative Reorganization Act of 1946 (2 U.S.C. 31) (relating to cost-of-living adjustments for Members of Congress) for any fiscal year in which the Congressional Budget Office determines there is a Federal budget deficit.
